üá¨üáß Review ‚Äì Diablo IV (EN)
üëç Recommended, with reservations

Diablo IV is a strong ARPG with an excellent dark atmosphere, great visuals, and satisfying combat. The story campaign is one of the best in the series, and character building feels rewarding, especially in the early game.

However, the longer you play, the more issues appear: repetitive endgame grind, seasonal balance decisions, and aggressive monetization (battle pass, cash shop) that doesn‚Äôt sit well in a full-price game. Always-online requirement can also be annoying.

Pros:

Dark atmosphere and top-tier visuals

Very good story campaign

Smooth and impactful combat

Cons:

Repetitive endgame

Heavy monetization

Always-online requirement

Final thoughts:
A great experience at the beginning and a solid entry for Diablo fans, but it may lose its charm over time. Best enjoyed on sale.

Aged like wine. I played Diablo IV at launch, and it was fine/alright, but I fell off after one season. I've been playing through season 11 to prep for the next expansion (also playing VoH for the first time), and it feels like everything I wanted from a new Diablo game. It's also nice to no longer have to jump through hoops to play it on Steam Deck.
its purdy

You drop into Sanctuary, pick your class, and immediately feel like an absolute unit. The combat? Chef‚Äôs kiss. Every swing, every spell, every corpse explosion hits like a freight train made of pure dopamine. Barbarian spinning to win, Sorceress turning the screen into a fireworks show, Rogue darting around like he‚Äôs too fast for the laws of physics‚Äîdoesn‚Äôt matter. You feel unstoppable. The world is dark, gorgeous, and dripping with that classic Diablo vibe. Lilith shows up looking like she could step on you and you‚Äôd thank her. 10/10 atmosphere, no notes.

Seasons keep dropping new toys, new builds, new ways to delete hordes of demons in increasingly unhinged ways. Infernal Hordes? More like Infernal Copium for the weak. You‚Äôre out here farming waves like it‚Äôs your job and you‚Äôre employee of the month every month.

Now, the endgame. Ah yes. The Pit. Torment 4. Trying to push past Paragon 200 toward that glorious 300. The game looks you dead in the eye, flexes, and says ‚ÄúProve you belong here, bro.‚Äù

You need 12/12 Greater Affixes. You need triple mythic uniques that don‚Äôt drop. You need masterworking to hit 12 without bricking your item for the 47th time. One misplaced roll and it‚Äôs back to Nightmare Dungeon #682. The RNG is not random‚Äîit‚Äôs personal. It hates you specifically. You will sacrifice 47 altars of Lilith and still get boots with +movement speed instead of the one stat you need.

But here‚Äôs the thing: **real Chads don‚Äôt complain about the grind.** Weaklings quit at Pit 80 and cry on Reddit. True 500+ hour gigachads stare into the abyss of endless material farming, laugh, and whisper ‚Äúthank you sir may I have another.‚Äù The pain is the point. Every failed temper, every bricked item, every 0.0001% drop that ghosts you‚Äîit‚Äôs building character. You emerge from the Pit battered, broken, and somehow stronger, like you just did 1000 push-ups while Lilith roasted your life choices.

Diablo 4 doesn‚Äôt respect your time. It respects your **will.**

So yes, it‚Äôs brutal. Yes, getting to Paragon 300 is basically self-inflicted war crime. But when you finally delete a screen of demons in 0.3 seconds with your perfectly rolled build? When you clear Pit 150 and the game finally bows?

**Chef‚Äôs kiss.** Absolute cinema. 9.5/10.

This game doesn‚Äôt deserve to be called Diablo. It‚Äôs a pay-to-win hack-and-slash made by developers milking their studio‚Äôs legacy.

Diablo 4, at this point, is much better than it was at launch, but still far from perfect.

The game promised an open world, visceral combat, and endless loot, and a lot of the time it delivers on that. Other times, it just makes you want to slap Blizzard across the face.


üìú The beginning of my experience:
I played at a slow pace, with no rush to reach the endgame, and the first thing that stood out was the weight of the world. Not in an overdone ‚Äúdark fantasy‚Äù way, but in a sense of exhaustion.

Sanctuary feels like a place where nothing worked out, where people no longer expect salvation. And that works. The story doesn‚Äôt try to impress you every second. It walks alongside you.

Lilith, in particular, isn‚Äôt a villain who screams evil. She questions, provokes, and sometimes makes way too much sense. More than once, I found myself more uncomfortable with the so-called ‚Äúheroes‚Äù than with her.


üç∫ My overall take:
Diablo 4 today is a functional, solid game that finally aligns with what it promised, but it still carries questionable Blizzard decisions that feel like they were made by a committee, not by people who actually play.

It delivers good combat, a heavy atmosphere, and addictive progression, as long as you accept that part of your time will be spent running recycled content in exchange for loot that‚Äôs almost good.

The expansion improves pacing, adds real build options, and the Paladin comes in as a well-designed class, not a band-aid fix. Even so, the game suffers from the same old issue. Once the new content runs out, it becomes clear the endgame still needs more purpose than just ‚Äúmaking numbers go up for no real reason.‚Äù

If you like the style, you‚Äôll have fun. If you‚Äôre expecting something revolutionary, you‚Äôll eventually realize this is controlled evolution, not bold ambition.

I'm a very casual player but I've enjoyed this far more than Diablo 3 which simply got boring after a while. The scenery and monster design is gorgeous: I frequently catch myself just stopping for a bit to look at everything (I seriously want a map maker so that I can make visual handouts for my D&D campaign). The game play is fast and crazy, but it's easy to change your playstyle instantly via respeccing. Like any other game of this genre, it gets repetitive, but the promise of new cosmetic items is always pulling me back it, which is quite silly in retrospect but whatever, I've been having fun so far. A bit pricey, but no regrets yet. I like that the only in-game store items are just cosmetics; no "pay to win" structure here at all. Fun for casuals, I can't comment on the viability of "serious" play.

I think this game is not worth at full price. If it is on sale--including LoH, buy it. The gameplay is clean and it feels good to get loot. Bosses are well-designed and the fights are usually fun--screw you uber lilith. There seems to be a lack of bug fixing which is tragic considering its a AAA company but what can ya do. I do however hate that progression is forced to pull you into dlc content, I have never been a fan of situations like that because they feel incredibly money hungry.

Druid is really fun I recommend it to people who like turning into a bear or werewolf.

TL;DR if the game is on sale buy it, its quite good.
